Secondary reasons for AMR: Among the 100 tested strains,19 showed resistance to amikacin. Five aminoglycoside-modifying enzymes(AMEs) genes were detected.
Other AMR: Four categories of efflux pumps were found in the current study, including the multi drug and toxic compound extrusion(MATE) family, the small multi drug-resistance(SMR) family trans-porters, the resistance-nodulation- division(RND) superfamily, and the major facilitator superfamily(MFS). Within these different pumps the RND(ade FGH, adeIJK and adeL), MATE(abeM) and SMR(abeS) were most frequent and found in 99–100% of isolates
Sensitive to: colistin (100%) while 80% were sensitive to tigecycline and 53.3 % were sensitive to carbapenems
Resistant to: chloramphenicol (100%), followed by fosfomycin (96%) and cefotaxime (95%) colistin (3%), trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (17%), tigecycline (19%), and amikacin (19%)
Plant complexes: Hexahydroxy diphenoyl ester vescalagin-Lythrum salicaria-Agar well diffusion test      Ellagic acid - Rosa rugosa - MIC, MBC          Berberine - Coptidis chinensis Franch - CFU      Eugenol - Syzygium aromaticum - MIC, CFU      Curcumin - Curcuma longa - MIC, time kill assay, FIC index, CFU

Primary reasons for AMR: low outer membrane pemeability,antibiotic inactivating enzyme(b-lactamases- destroy beta lactam rings)
Sensitive to: Only combination drugs like Ticarcillin + Clavulanic acid, Piperacillin + Tazobactum, Cefoperazone + Sulbactum, Cefotaxime + Sulbactum, Ceftriaxome + Sulbactum and monotherapy of amikacin showed higher sensitivity to Pseudomonas infections; however, the maximum sensitivity was shown by the Carbapenems.

Secondary reasons for AMR: Modification of target Penicillin- Binding Protein (PBP),Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs, antibiotic efflux system
Sensitive to: All the isolates were sensitive to imipenem. The majority of ESBL producers (>80%) were sensitive to meropenem, piperacillin-tazobactam, and amikacin. Only 50% of ESBL isolates were sensitive to gentamicin.
Resistant to: penicillins, cephalosporins, and the monobactam aztreonam.

Secondary reasons for AMR: enzymes that increase the MIC of aminoglycosides and prevent synergism
Other AMR: Lincosamides and streptogramins- lsa gene confers drug efflux ability
Sensitive to: All strains of E. faecium were sensitive to glycopeptides (vancomycin and teicoplanin), 32% strains were sensitive to penicillin, 19% to tetracycline 14% to ciprofloxacin and 50% to nitrofurantoin.

Primary reasons for AMR: b-lactamase production; β-Lactam antibiotics bind at the active site serine of the TP in PBP2 by acting as structural analogues of D-Ala4-D-Ala5. The β-lactam bond is broken and a penicilloyl-O-serine intermediate is formed
Other AMR: altered topoisomerase IV and DNA gyrase expression for fluoroquinolones, formation of alternative pathways for sulphonamides,presence of acetyltransferase to chloramphenicol, decrease in accumulation to macrolide antibiotics
Sensitive to:
The overall percentages of S. aureus sensitive to
 the tested antibiotics were as follows: methicillin 85%, penicillin 8%,
 gentamicin 89%, ciprofloxacin 85%, erythromycin 80%, fusidic acid 96%, 
mupirocin 98%.
Resistant to: methicillin, amoxicillin, penicillin, oxacillin, and other common antibiotics known as cephalosporins.

Primary reasons for AMR: abolished activity for an electron acceptor hence drug unable to activate
Secondary reasons for AMR: point mutations: substitutions cause decreased affiinity  of  the  ribosomes  for  macrolides,  resulting  in increased  resistance
Sensitive to: Helicobacter pylori is very sensitive to amoxicillin both in vivo and in vitro. Like other penicillins, amoxicillin works by inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis, leading to cell death. Amoxicillin has topical intraluminal activity at the level of the gastric mucosa, as well as systemic activity.
Resistant to: 100% to ampicillin, penicillin and co-amoxiclav; 97.14% to amoxicillin, 97.85% to metronidazole, 47.85% to erythromycin, 13.57% to clarithromycin; 5, 2.86 and 0.71% to doxycycline, tetracycline and minocycline respectively.

Secondary reasons for AMR: protection of the ribosomal binding site of tetracycline by ribosomal protection proteins (RPPs),the enzymatic degradation of tetracyclines found in Bacteroides (TETRACYCLINE)
Other AMR: decreased outer membrane permeability,antibiotic efflux system,
Sensitive to: all Campylobacter strains were sensitive to chloramphenicol, erythromycin, gentamicin, nalidixic acid, norfloxacin, and tetracycline
Resistant to: nalidixic acid, tetracycline, fluoroquinolones, and macrolides

Sensitive to: Salmonella isolates were found to be sensitive to chloramphenicol (MIC: 3.89±6.94 µg/mL), cefixime (MIC: 0.13±0.11 µg/mL), azithromycin (MIC: 3.32±2.19 µg/mL), and ceftriaxone (MIC: 0.11±0.18 µg/mL) and resistant to ofloxacin (MIC: 2.95±6.06 µg/mL).
Resistant to: Ampicillin 15 (3.4) Chloramphenicol17 (3.8) Tetracycline05 (1.1) Cotrimoxazole21 (4.7) Streptomycin19 (4.3) Nalidixic acid436 (97.8) Ofloxacin93 (20.9) Levofloxacin93 (20.9)

Secondary reasons for AMR: enhanced anti-microbial efflux (by overexpressing, for example, the MtrCDE effluxpumps), and decreased antimicrobial influx (e.g., through the PorBporin)
Sensitive to: sensitive to cefpodoxime, ceftriaxone and azithromycin.
Resistant to: some strains have developed high-level resistance to ceftriaxone, Resistance against ciprofloxacin, penicillin, tetracycline and nalidixic acid were 85.1%, 99.2%, 84.8% and 99.7% respectively.

Secondary reasons for AMR: Macrolides through efflux (mef gene), Alteration of ribosomal target througherm(B)
Other AMR: Lincosamides, Alteration of ribosomal target througherm(B)Clonal spread (erm-mediated)

Primary reasons for AMR: b-lactamase production is seen in some strains which are resistant to penicillin
Sensitive to: Almost all isolates were susceptible to amoxicillin/clavulanate, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefuroxime, and ciprofloxacin, while the susceptibility rate to trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole was only 50.1%
Resistant to: penicillin antibiotic group (eg, 67% for ampicillin) and macrolides (eg, 46% for erythromycin),  cefuroxime, ampicillin/sulbactam, cefotaxime, clarithromycin, and sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim were 72.1% (440/610), 95.9%, 96.4% (588/610), 81.8% (499/610), and 36.4% (222/610), respectively.

Primary reasons for AMR: b-lactamase production is seen primarily, class a b-lactamase resistance
Secondary reasons for AMR: extrusion of drugs by active efflux pumps
Other AMR: decrease in cellular permeability, and overexpression of drug-modifying and -inactivating enzymes or target modification by mutation
Sensitive to: 33% of the isolates were sensitive to amoxicillin, cotrimoxazole and ciprofloxacin and one isolate is resistant to third generation cephalosporin
Resistant to: ampicillin, amoxicillin, erythromycin and multi-drug resistant (MDR) with the pooled resistance proportions of 83.1% (95% CI 75.7–88.6), 84.1% (95% CI 75.6–90.1), 86.5% (95% CI 70.9–94.4) and 83.2% (95% CI 77.1–87.9), respectively.
